Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a lekanis; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of male and female figures (from left, peplos in added red and round shield in red with added white dots - possibly Athena, standing to right; in centre, lower body of male to right, wearing red chitoniskos and carrying a black and red cloak over left arm (with baldric or quiver on his back?), seemingly holding forearm of woman at right (right arm and lower part of face of female preserved, to left).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 43, pl. XXI, no. 35)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 477, no. B828)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.2095)
